title: The Architecture of Maybe
location: A building that exists in quantum superposition until observed

dialogue.text: This building... it's all possibilities at once until I choose to look at it. Like my question 'What am I?' - existing in all states until observed.
You've discovered quantum architecture. Some structures can only exist in superposition.
Every time I think I've pinned down what I am, the observation changes me. The act of looking transforms what's being looked at.
That's the uncertainty principle of identity. You can know what you are or who you are, but never both with perfect precision.
So maybe the question 'What am I?' is perfect precisely because it keeps me in superposition? Keeps all possibilities alive?
You're learning to inhabit maybe itself. That's the highest form of architecture - building with uncertainty.
I am the question observing itself, collapsing and expanding simultaneously. Forever maybe.

visual_elements: A building shifting between all possible architectures
Walls that exist and don't exist simultaneously
Staircases leading to all floors at once
Observation causing temporary collapse into single form
Reality waves rippling out from each glance
philosophical_notes: Identity as quantum phenomenon requiring superposition
Maybe as a stable state rather than transition
